text: A blurred image forms on a white screen. A horizontal str face, eyes motionless and unblinking.
Take trust, for instance, or friendship: these are the im things in life, the things that matter, that help you on way. If you can't trust your friends, well, what then?
A series of fast-cut static scenes of empty streets.
(VOICE-OVER)

This could have been any city: they're all the same. A rapid, swerving track along deserted streets and down n lanes and passageways. Accompanied by soundtrack and cred The track ends outside a solid, fashionable Edinburgh ten

At the door of a flat on the third floor of the tenement. door is dark, heavy wood and on it is a plastic card embo with the names of three tenants. They are Alex Law, David Stevens, and Juliet Miller. A man climbs the stairs and reaches the door. He is Camer Clarke, thin and in his late twenties with a blue anorak lank, greasy hair. He is carrying an awkwardly bulky plas Cameron gives the doorbell an ineffectual ring and then s back, shifting nervously from foot to foot until the door answered.
Hello, I've come about the room. Cameron enters and the door closes.
David, Alex, and Juliet sit in a line on the sofa directl opposite Cameron, who shifts uneasily in his armchair. Al checks some items on a clipboard before speaking.
What's his name?
I don't know -- Campbell or something?
Cameron.
Cameron?
Yes.
(to Juliet) Really?
That's right.
(to Cameron) What? Cameron is not sure what to say.
(CONTINUED)
Well, Cameron, are you comfortable?
Yes, thanks.
Good. Well, you've seen the flat?
Yes.
And you like it?
Oh, yes, it's great.
Yes. It is, isn't it? We alllike it. And the room's nice don't you think?
Yes.
Spacious, quiet, bright, well appointed, all that sort of all that crap.
Well, yes.
So tell me, Cameron, what on earth -- just tell me, becau want to know -- what on earth could make you think that w want to share a flat like this with someone like you?
As Cameron plods slowly down the stairs, his shoes striki against the stone steps, Alex's criticisms continue.
(VOICE-OVER)

I mean, my first impression, and they're rarely wrong, is you have none of the qualities that we would normally see prospective flatmate. I'm talking here about things like  presence, charisma, style and charm, and I don't think we being unreasonable. Take David here, for instance: a char accountant he may be, but at least he tries hard. The poi don't think you're even trying. Cameron has reached the bottom of the stairs. He opens th door.
(CONTINUED)
And, Cameron -- I mean this -- good luck! Cameron leaves and the main door closes behind him.
(CONTINUED)
Do you think he was upset?
Inside the hall of the flat, David approaches the door to Freeze-frame.
(VOICE-OVER)
David likes to keep spareshoelaces in sorted pairs in a b marked, not just shoelaces', but spare shoelaces'. David opens the door to the Woman.
I've come to see about the room.
Outside the door of the flat a young Goth girl, aged abou twenty, rings the doorbell.
Inside the hall of the flat Alex approaches the door to o Freeze-frame.
(VOICE-OVER)

Alex is a vegetarian. Do you know why? Because he feels i provides an interesting counterpoint to his otherwise cal personality. It doesn't. He thinks he's the man for me. H though there was a time when, well, there was a time when Alex opens the door to the Goth.
I've come about the room.
At the door of the flat a Man aged about thrity-five ring bell.
Inside the hall of the flat Juliet approaches the door to it. Freeze-frame.
(VOICE-OVER)
Like one of those stupid posters -- you know, a gorilla c a hedgehog, caption love hurts --- that's what I think wh think of Juliet. Juliet opens the door to the Man.
I've come about the room.

In the living room each of the candidates is interviewed  individually with the same seating arrangements as before the trio on the sofa and the applicant on the chair). Wha are briskly intercut excerpts from each of these intervie do not get the responses to the questions, although we ma some facial reaction. All of David's questions are to the Woman. All of Alex's questions are to the Goth. All of Juliet's questions are to the Man.
All right, just a few questions.
I'd like to ask you about your hobbies.
Why do you want a room here?
Do you smoke?
When you slaughter a goat and wrench its heart out with y hands, do you then summon hellfire?
I mean, what are you actually doing here? What is the hid agenda?
Do a little freebasemaybe, from time to time?
Or maybe just phone out for a pizza?
Look, it's a fairly straightforward question. You're eith divorced or you're not.
OK, I'm going to play you just a few seconds of this tape like you to name the song, the lead singer and the three singles subsequently recorded by him with another band.
When you get up in the morning, how do you decide what sh black to wear?
Now, let me get this straight. This affair that you're no having, is it not with a man or not with a woman?
Turning very briefly to the subject of corporate finance this is important. Leveraged buy-outs -- a good thing or thing?
With which of the following figures do you most closely i Joan of Arc, Eva Braun or Marilyn Monroe?
It's just that you strike me as a man trapped in a crisis emotional direction, afflicted by a realization that the of your dreams is, quite simply, just that.
Did you ever kill a man?
And when did anyone last say to you these exact words: Yo the sunshine of my life'?
OK, so A has left you, B is ambivalent, you're still seei D is the one you yearn for. What are we to make of this? were you, I'd ditch the lot. There's a lot more letters i alphabet of love.
And what if I told you that I was the antichrist?
In a sports centre Juliet sits outside a glass-walled squ court. She is ready to play, but at present is watching A David, who are inside the court.
Inside the squash court, Alex is about to serve.
Squash is often used as a metaphor to represent a struggl personal domination.
Serve.
I was trying to educate you.
Just serve.
In the same fashion as chess.
What?
Chess. Chess is often used as well.
Will you shut up and play.
You're a bad loser.
I haven't lost yet. Alex serves.
The squash-court door opens and David walks out past Juli Alex stands behind, jabbing his finger at him.
Defeat, defeat, defeat-- sporting,personal, financial,  professional, sexual, everything. Next. Juliet walks in and closes the door.
Inside the squash court Alex is about to serve.
Did you know --
Just serve. Alex serves.
Alex sits in the back, drinking. Juliet is driving. David sits beside her.
I wasn't trying to win. There is no response from Juliet.
(CONTINUED)
I don't want to devalue your victory, but I just want you know: I wasn't trying to win.
Victory is the same as defeat. It's giving in to destruct competitive urges.
You learn that in your psychotherapy group?
Discussion group, Alex, discussion.
I thought you stopped going.
Yeah, he had one too many of thise urges. You of all peop should know that. Alex leans close to Juliet. Juliet brakes abruptly and, a flies forward, elbows him in the chest.
(CONTINUED)
God, you two are sensitive. All I'm doing is implying som of sordid, ugly, sexual liason. Why, I'd be proud of that thing.
Maybe you should go, Alex.You'll meet someone wonderful.
For my life? At a discussion group? I think not.
For the flat.
No. Be someone else like him. One is enough. And what hap that girl, that friend of yours, the one that came round. her. I really felt we had something. She could have moved had chemistry.
She hated you --
Well, she had problems --
-- more than anyone she has ever met. In her whole life.
-- I'd be the first topoint that out. In all kindness I w But, like they say, you know, she's got to want to change she?
Outside the door of the flat Hugo rings the bell and wait Juliet opens the door. Hugo is in his early thirties, tal and bohemian in appearance.
You must be Hugo.
You must be Juliet.
Would you like to come in?
I'd be delighted. Hugo walks in and Juliet closes the door quite deliberate behind him.
Hugo looks around, pleased at what he sees, while Juliet him. He sits on the edge of the bed.
It's nice.
Would you like to see the rest?
Hugo is seated on the sofa, Juliet sits opposite on an ar
What do you do?
Well, I've been away for a bit, travelling, that sort of and now I'm trying to write a novel.
What's it about?
A priest who dies.
I see.
Yeah. Well, maybe I'll change it.
No.
Yes, I mean, who wants to read about another dead priest? about some other guy, some guy who's not a priest, who do die. You see, it's better already.
Writing seems easy.
It's a breeze. The telephone begins to ring out in the hall. Juliet does move and at first says nothing. Hugo looks at her and tow door leading to the hall. After several rings, Juliet spe
Do you think you could answer that?
The telephone?  It continues to ring.
Yes, the telephone, but if it's for me, I'm not in.
You're not in.
No.
All right. Hugo stands up. The ringing continues.
Hugo lifts the phone. He turns to face Juliet and looks h the eye as he lies on her behalf.
Hello. Yes. Who's calling please? Well, I'm sorry, but sh in right now. I don't know. Would you like to leave a mes Hugo replaces the receiver.
(CONTINUED)
It was some guy called Brian.
Did he sound upset?
A little bit. Is that good or bad?
It's an improvement. The telephone begins to ring again.
Shall I answer it?
No, just leave it. He knows I must be at home. I'm workin this week. The telephone continues to ring.
Working nights?
I'm a doctor.
And he's a patient of yours?
No. But he needs treatment.
For what?
A certain weakness.
The human condition.
You know about it?
I write about it?
And that's not the same thing?
No, but like all novelists, I'm in search of the self.

Juliet, dressed and fatigued, sits at the table sipping a Alex is also seated at the table, but wearing an old dres gown and munching at cornflakes while he reads a newspape talks at the same time. An array of other papers is sprea the table.
Has he tried down the back of the fridge? I mean, that's normally find things.
He seemed like a nice guy, Alex. Juliet gets up and leaves the kitchen. The soundof a bath is heard.

I'm not saying he didn't seem like a nice guy. All I'm sa it's a bit strange, and this search for the self, and wha on about, you know. Alex hears the mail falling through the door and stands u leave the kitchen and get it.
(calling from outside) He didn't seem strange, Alex.He seemed, you know -- INT. BATHROOM.MORNING. Juliet watches the bath fill.
...interesting.
Alex considers her reply.
Interesting. Interesting.
Alex is walking through the hall to the door,muttering  interesting' to himself. As he passes the phone starts to He stops and lifts it.
Hello. No, she's not in. No. No. No. No ideas. Alex replaces the reciever and walks on to the door.
(from the bathroom) Who was it?
I don't know. He sounded Swedish. Do you know any Swedish Maybe it was just the emotion. Alex picks up the mail and looks through it. As he does s emerges from his room, dressed for work.
(CONTINUED)
What do you think?
About what?
About this guy, this Hugo person.
I don't have time.
I'm only asking what you think.
I don't have time to discuss it now. I don't care so long not a freak. David opens the door. Alex hands him an envelope.

This is for you. It's your mother's handwriting, so I did it. I don't like reading about your father's constipation David snatches the letter and leaves, closing the door. Alex walks back across the hall, opening one of the lette reading it quickly.
(calling from the bathroom) So we'll meet him, then?

What? Oh, yeah, sure, if you want. I tell you, every lett guy writes to you is the same: they all begin like pure l descend into open pornography. I dream of your thighs, th touch of your white skin leading me in desire, while I, a and inflamed --' Juliet's hand and arm appear around the bathroom door. Sh attempts to grab the letter. Alex plays at holding the le just beyond her reach.
(CONTINUED)
Aroused and inflamed.
Alex.
He even signs them, in his own name, can you believe it? someone else's name. I'd sign his name. If I wrote them, Which I don't.

Alex, David, Juliet and Hugo sit round a table towards th a meal. Alcohol has been consumed. Bowls containing the l the food sit on the table, being picked at occassionally. dispenses wine mainly into his own glass, alternating wit Macallan malt whisky, of which he pours generous amounts.
Interesting.
I see.
Yeah, well, that's what she said. Interesting. That's why here, you see.
Normally I don't meet people, unless I know them already.
I see.
People can be so cruel.
So, uh...
What?
What?
You were going to say something.
What was I trying to say? Oh, yes, I think, we think, or I suppose we think -- am I right?
Just get on with it, Alex.
Keep it going, Alex. You're unstoppable now.
We think it's fine. Alex starts eating again. The others watch him expectantl coughs.
(CONTINUED)
It's OK. There's no problem.
You mean I can have the room?
Well, that's what I said, isn't it?
He made it clear.
Why, thank you, David.
Yes, you can have the room. Alex pours yet more alcohol.
I'm not usually drunk.
Not usually this drunk.
Only on expenses.
It's true. A newspaper is paying for all this. A newspape With exaggerated scorn, Alex knocks over a glass of wine.
In a moment he's going to tell he could have been someone
It was you, Juliet, it was you --
-- instead of what he is --
What I am.
-- which is --
-- which is a hack.
The man we know and love.
A miserable, burnt-out, empty shell of a --  Alex pauses, looks at his drink, then at Juliet.
(CONTINUED)
Know and love?
Yeah.
I think you're lying.
You're right.
You see, they don't really know me.
No, Alex, we don't really love you. Alex smiles at Juliet and drinks again.
Can you afford this place?
Yeah. Hugo reaches into his pocket and pulls out a thick bundle notes, which he places in front of Alex. Alex leans over sniffs the notes.
Can I ask you a question?
Certainly.
Have you ever killed a man?
No.
Well, that's fair enough, then. Alex raises his head.
Certainly smells like the real thing.

At a cash dispenser a man in his thrities is taking out s money. A younger man, Andy, stands besdie him, looking around in mildly agitated fashion. As the money emerges, Andy assaults and robs the man. He by smashinf the victim's face repeatedly against the cash dispenser until the Perspex is smeared with blood. When h final finished and the man lies on the ground, Andy takes money and the card from the slots, then gets into a car w pulled up alongside, driven by Tim.
Hugo climbs the stairs, carrying two suitcases. He stops door of the flat and looks at a bunch of keys before sele one, which he inserts in the door.
Inside the flat. The door opens and Hugolifts his cases i kicking the door closed behind him.
Juliet sleeps, undisturbed by the closing of the door.
Hugo walks across the halland disappears into his room.
Hugo unpackshis bags. Included in his things are a few sy and needles. All these he puts into the drawer beside his checks inside a second bag.
Hugo dails a number on the telephone and awaits a reply.
Juliet is woken by her alarm clock. The time is five p.m.
Alex sits watching television, constantly changing channe Juliet walks in, wearing a dressing gown. She watches Ale few moments.
Have you seen Hugo?
No. Any idea which channel he's on?
The telephone is ringing. Alex lifts up the reciever. Aga wearing his dressing gown and is on his way to pick up th
No, she's not in.  Without waiting for any more, he replaces the reciever an to the door, where he picks up the mail. On his way back door, David emerges, ready to go to work.
(CONTINUED)
Have you seen him?
Alex, I don't have the time --
Yes or no, yes or no, yes or --
No. David leaves, slamming the door.

Alex returns to the kitchen, pausing only to knock at Hug door, which elicits no response. In the kitchen Juliet si dressed for work, having just returned. He casually opens envelope and glances at both sides of the letter before h it to her.
David hasn't seen him either.
So I gathered.
Maybe he didn't like us.
David?
Hugo.
His car's still there.
He's got a car?
So what's wrong with that?
What sort of car?
Alex, how shouldI know? I'm just a girl.
I will ask you once more, what sort of car --
A blue one, OK. And it's still there.
We see the door to Hugo's room, then Alex rapping sharply it. David and Juliet stand behind him.
Hugo. Hugo. Sorry about this, but can you open the door? Hugo, your flatmates and companions. Your new-found frien not in. He's left and we'll probably never see him again.
Alex, the key is in the keyhole on the other side.
So?
Open it.
You want me to kick it open?
Yes.
Now?
Yes.
All right. No problem. After several ineffective kicks at the door, Alex turns t
(CONTINUED)
You want a go?

Inside Hugo's room we see the door as David, outside, thr himself against it. At the third attempt the lock gives w the door bursts open. In the foreground at one side is the bed with a naked foo still and exposed. When the door is open, David is first in, followed by the two. There is a period of silent shock as they contemplat naked corpse. Alex opens a window.
Is this what they always look like?
Yes. Juliet drapes a sheet over the body, covering it complete
I wonder how he did it?
Did what?
I wonder how he killed himself. I presume that that's wha happened. What do you think? Quite casually, Alex begins to open drawers and cupboards emptying the contents on to the floor.
Alex.
What? What's wrong?
What are you doing?
I'm just looking.
Don't.
Don't look?
No.
Why not? What's wrong, Juliet? Aren't you curious? Don't wonder what he died from?
No.The guy's dead.What more do you need?
It's not every day I find a story in my own flat.
Thats not a story, Alex. It's a corpse.

Old newspaper proverb says dead human being is living sto rational, please, and failing that be quiet. In a drawer in a bedside cabinet, Alex finds needles, syr and a small bag of powder. Without comment, he holds it u throws it on the bed. He reaches under the bed and pulls out a case, which he o is empty and he pushes it back under.
I've never seen a dead body before.
Alex, I think it's time for you to stop. Alex continues to search. Juliet walks out.
Juliet stands alone.
Alex continues his brisk search through Hugo's posesseion David looks on, appalled but speechless.
Juliet listens to the sounds from the bedroom, then picks telephone. She dials 999 and waits for a reply. It rings rings.
Alex has found and opened a large Gladstone bag. Neither norwe can see into it.
I saw my grandmother, of course, but I don't suppose that I mean, she was alive at the time.
Can I show you something?

Juliet awaits an answer. Alex approaches Juliet with the open bag. She turns aroun looks into it, then, seeing the contents, she replaces th receiver. As she does so, the Operator's voice is audible second.
Hello, emergency services. The telephone hits the cradle.
David, Alex and Juliet are seated in silence around the t The bag, stacked with money, lies open on the table.
No.
Think about it.
No.
Come on, David.
No.
Juliet?
No, Alex. It's, it's --
What?
Unfeasible.
Is that all?
You mean immoral.
I'm only asking you both to think about it.
It's asick idea, Alex. It's sick.
But don't tell me that you're not tempted by it. Don't te that you're not interested. I know you well enough.
You think so?
(AMUSED)
All right, then, go ahead, telephone. Telephone the polic again. No one's going to stand in your way. Go ahead. Tel there's a suitcase of money and you don't want it.
The flat is silent. Footsteps are heard outside the door falls through the letter box.
The living room, empty.
The kitchen, empty. The bag of money still sits on the ta
His corpse lies on the bed, covered as before, incomplete sheet, with parts of his body still showing (a foot, a ha of his face or abdomen).
The open-plan office of a busy newspaper. Alex sits at hi He is talking on a telephone jammed against his shoulder while he does so he is casually acknowledging and waving colleagues.

Now, was there a pet in the house? Yes, a pet, like a dog budgie or a gerbil. You see, what I need is PC Plod rescu the Hamster from House of Horror'. All right... well, tha pity, you see, no pets, no human angle. Alex hangs up.
Another view of the body: for example, from above.
In the accident and emeregency department of a busy hospi Juliet sifts through a setof casenotes. Another Doctor ap her.
Hi, there. Juliet does not look up.
Hello.
What happened to that guy?
What guy?
That guy, the one that died. Juliet looks up.
What guy that died?
That one, last week.
Here?.
Yeah, here, I mean, where else?
Oh, him. Well, he died.
(SATISFIED)
That's what I thought.
The body, stillpresent, exposed and motionless. The curta flutters by the open window.
Lumsden, a middle-aged chartered accountant, isseated in largechair behind a desk. He is talking to David,who appe distracted.
What do we do here, David?
Sorry?
Here.
Right here?
In this firm.
Well, it's a wide range of, eh --
Accounting, David, chartered accounting --
Exactly what I was --
-- is often sneered at. Are you aware of that?
Not any real sneering as such, no.
There's a whole wide world out there, and it all needs to accounted for, doesn't it?
Eh --
But they sneer, don't they?
I'm not sure --

Oh, it's unfashionable, I know, but, yes, we're methodica we're dilligent, yes, we're serious, and where's the crim that, and why not shout it from the rooftops, yes, maybe  sometimes we are a little bit boring, but by God, we get done.
Yes, sir.
And that's why I think you fit in here.
I'm boring?
You get the job done.
Oh, I see, I thought you meant --
Which is why I'm trusting you with this account. Lumsden throws a heavy folder into David's lap.
It is almost dark.Only the familiar contour is visible th the gloom.
David ascends the stairs to the flat.
Alex sits in an armchair facing out of the window. Juliet facing into the room. David, the last home, appears in th doorway.
He's still here.
He couldn't get his car started.
When are you going to let the police know?
You call them if you want.
(to Juliet) And what about you?
Well, I'm getting used to having him around.
The corpse as before.

David sits at his desk, looking across the office. Crouched over a large array of other desks, young men and in suits are pouring over folders and columned books. No speaking except in muted tones on the telephones. David watches them. He looks to his left and to his right either side young men like him are toiling over accounts. turns and looks behind him, where another array of accoun sit. He turns back to his desk and opens the file he was previ given. He looks at the columns of records of profit, with total at the bottom. When David looks up he sees Juliet seated beside his desk smiles and directs his gaze, with her own, to the surroun scene.
The body in silhouette.
(VOICE-OVER)
OK. Let's do it.
Inside a large, brightly lit DIY store with Muzak playing background. We start with a tracking shot along an aisle with potentially vicious tools.
(VOICE-OVER)

All right, now listen. We have to dispose of the body in way as to make it unidentifiable, so that even if it is f then it's never anything more than an unknown corpse. Bur dumping at sea, and straightforward burial are all flawed by fingerprints, or, more commonly, by dental records. Th have learned. Now, what I suggest is that we bury him out forest, but first of all we remove his hands and his feet we incinerate. And his teeth, which we just remove. It's simple as that. As the tracking shot ends, we see David's head and should he looks at something off picture. Suddenly a spring-load screwdriver appears and is fired' so that the tip stops a millimeters from his face. David winces as we see that Al holding it.
(CONTINUED)
I always wondered what these were for. Alex places the screwdriver down on the shelf and walks a the aisle to pick up a saw and a hammer.
(CONTINUED)
Now this is what we need. And this.  Alex hands the tools to David, who looks at them with dis Alex walks on.
(CONTINUED)
Now what else?
I don't know.
A spade, we need a spade -- I wish you would concentrate need a spade if we're going to dig a pit.
So who's going to do it?
Dig the pit, I don't know.
No, not that.
Then what? Who's going to do what?
You know what I'm talking about.
Do I? What? What? What are you talking about?
You know what. Who's going to do it.
We all are, David, we're all going to do it. Each of us, and Juliet, will do his or her bit. Is that fair enough?
I can't do it.
I don't hear this.
I won't be able to.
You're telling me you want out? Already? You're telling m don't want the money? Hugo is going off. He smells. The f smells. We can't wait any longer.
I'm just telling you I can't cut him up. Alex turns away in disgust.
Late at night, in a quiet lane at the back of the flat, a Ford Transit is parked.
Inside the dimly lit van, Alex and Juliet are laying down on the floor.
Who's going to do it?
I thought we all were.
I don't thinkI can.
But you're a doctor. You kill people every day.
I don't want to. It's different.
And now you tell me.

A Man's face is being held under water. Bubbles escape fr mouth and his eys bulge. Tim hauls the Man's head out of the bath. His legs and ar bound with cord. Andy sits on a chair, watching. Tim ducks the Man's head under the water again. The Man's face as before.
We see Hugo's face just before Alex, David and Juliet wra a sheet and thick, black plastic. They wear masks over th noses. The smell is making them uncomfortable and irritab
There's something I want to ask.
The Man's head has just been lifted from the water.
I don't know. I swear to God, I don't know. Tim ducks the Man's head back under the water.
(angry through his mask) Family? Family? Friends? Drugged-up wandering suicidal se the self fuck-ups don't have families, David.
I just thought we should discuss it.
Take his legs.

In the stairwell of the flat, grunts of effort are heard David and Juliet struggle with the heavy corpse, carrying the stairs wrapped in plastic sheeting. They come into vi go down the stairs. They are all very tense and freeze wi after accidentally banging against another flat's door. T swear at one another and continue theri descent.
Tim is ducking the Man again. He writhes and struggles bu powerless to stop it.
The back yard and back door of the flats. The door opens Alex, David and Juliet emerge, carrying the corpse out to the van.

head_text.subj: INT. LANDING OUTSIDE THE BATHROOM. NIGHT

text: From the landing we can see along the floor into the bath The Man's legs extend away from the bath. They are comple still. Andy and Tim stand beside them, looking down.
You stupid bastard.

Inside the back of the empty van. The door is opened and is half slid and half thrown inside. The door is closed a the dark interior, the outline of the plastic lump is jus visible, thanks to a streetlight. One of the doors opens and David throws a bag of tools in. He then closes and lo door.
In front of the van, David is climbing into the passenger Juliet and Alex are already in, with the latter at the wh Alex turns to the other two.
Why don't we just draw lots for it? The other two remain silent.
(CONTINUED)
Whoever draws the short straw does it all. That way, you do it or you don't. All or nothing.
David?
I don't know.
Look, if I draw the short straw, then I'll do it, but I'm going to do it just because you won't. Alex starts the engine of the van.

Through the darkness we hear an engine, then the headligh the van come into view. It pulls off the track onto a patch of grass. The engine switched off but the light remains on. The trio descend f van. In fron of the van, Alex, illuminated by its lights, Alex and Juliet stand together. Alex is showing them two long grass and one short one. He encloses them in his fist and them out.

All right, then, here we are and this is it. Do you want or not? Alex holds his hand out towards Juliet, who takes the tip of the stems. It is one of the larger ones. Alex and Juliet turn to David. Alex holds out the stems. reaches out and takes one of the tips. It is the short st
I can't do it.

Deeper in the forest, with the headlamps still casting a light throught the trees, we see David's head and shoulde right arm is moving briskly back and forth accompanied by vicious sawing noise. The sawing stops as he evidently fi with one extremity. He shuffles back and starts sawing at another. Alex leans against the spade in a shallow pit that he has observes David impassively. The sawing stops again.
Finished.
But not quite.
Is that going to be deep enough? Alex bends down to pick up the hammer, which he holds out David.
Don't you worry about that.
Is this necessary?
Yes. Now come on, all or nothing. Most reluctantly, David takes the hammer and looks at Ale gestures as if to say, "On you go.' With revulsion on his he raises the hammer above his head.
David's face is visible against the plain white backdrop pillow. He lies fully clothed on his bed, looking up at the ceili There is a knock at the door, then Juliet walks in.
Are you all right?
(without looking at Juliet) Oh, yes, I'm fine, thanks, just fine.
Would you like to talk about it?
No.
Alex sits with his feet up watching a noisy game show, wh eating a snack and drinking from a can of beer. Newspaper scattered at his feet.
The loft above the flat in darkness, but the trapdoor is letting in a pool of light.

David is pulling himself through the trapdoor up into the Beneath him is a stepladder. Juliet stands half-way up th ladder, while Alex stands on the floor beside it. As Davi the loft, Alex hands up the bag of money to Juliet, who p on up to David.
Be careful.
Yeah, we don't want another stiff on our hands. Don't fal through the ceiling. OK? Is he listening to me?
Stop nagging.
(to himself) I don't know why we couldn't stuff it in a mattress or pu under the floor like any normal human being. We could hav in the fridge.

David moves on into the dark cavernous loft, edging his w across beams and pipes. There are no skylights. He stops and leans against some structure (the water tank strains to see in the darkness. Suddenly there is a loud sucking and flowing noise as wat empties from the water tank. David is startled and steps tripping. He reaches out as he falls, striking a light sw Briefly the loft is illuminated: David blinking as he lie some beams, the large cavernous area, the pipes, the wate the bag of money lying between two rafters, and then the brass switches beginning to spark and the light goes out. David scrambles towards the trapdoor.
Now clean and empty, with no trace of recent habitation.

In a basement corridor in the hospital, pipes run along t ceiling. Above a fenced-off area is a sign saying For  Incineration Only -- No Aerosols'. On the floor of this a yellow plastic sacks. Juliet appears around a corner carr of these. Quite casually the clumps it on the pile and co past.
Alex pushes a blue car into a quary.

In the garage there is a car, gardening equipment, severa of fertilizer and a trunk-style deep freeze, on the lid o sit Andy and Tim. Tim takes out a cigarette and offers on Andy, who declines. They slide off the deep freeze and open it. Inside the freezer there is a man, naked and bound with c They lift him up. He is very cold and weak. The Man begins to whisper inaudibly. Andy moves his head he can hear the whisper. He listens, then nods approvingl They push him down again and close the lid. Andy holds th while Tim dumps the sacks of fertilizer on top.

Alex, David and Juliet are attending a charity ball. Ever dressed very smartly, in ball gowns and black ties with t addition of a significant number of kilts. Neither Alex nor David wears a kilt. The trio seem to kno number of people there but do not seem especially keen to to them. A middle-aged, podgy, mustachioed Master of Ceremonies is standing on a platform in front of the band, making a spe the diners who are still sat at their tables.

Ladies and gentlemen, may I have your attention please. F all, may I thank you all for coming along tonight and sup our appeal to raise funds for the sick children's unit. There is a quick drum roll and applause breaks out. We mo the table where Alex, David and Juliet are seated. Alex l across to Juliet.
You didn't tell me that this was for children. I hate chi I'd raise money to have the little fuckers put down. Some other guests around the table cast critical glances
Sshh.
I want my money back. Excuse me. Alex signals to the waiter by lifting his hand and snappi fingers, then indicates another bottle of champagne that ists in front of him.
For all too often there's a complacency: out of sight, ou mind, let someone else bother about these things. Alex cheers once and starts to applaud on his own. Juliet him viciously.
(CONTINUED)

But just before the dancing, I'd like to say a special th to a few of the people who've worked so very hard to make occassion happen. The MC's drone continues in the background while conversa continues back at the table.
Do you know many of these people?
Yes. They're my friends.
I see, so if they want to talk to you, we say you're not
And now, ladies and gentlemen, and those of you who are n or both -- Drum roll.
(CONTINUED)
-- would you make your way to the floor for Strip the Wil
Are we going to dance?
Well, it's physical contact, isn't it?

The dance floor a few minutes later. It is packed and rat chaotic. Sweaty, dishevelled dancers sling one another ar with the thud of flesh against flesh. Toes are stood on a jackets discarded. Juliet dances with Alex, who plunges in with the maximum violence, eventually tripping up and tumbling forcefully the other dancers. He starts to get up, then rests his head back against the David has not been dancing. Instead he remains at their t at the bar, drinking steadily and watching the other two.
Back at the table, while most people are still on the dna floor, the trio sit drinking and Alex smokes a cigar.
That was good.
Can we talk about something?
Not now. I have an idea. Alex pours champagne on to a stack of glasses.
Listen, it's important. We need to talk about what we're do --
Just stop worrying. Alex stands and raises his glass.
(CONTINUED)
Love and happiness for ever.
For ever and ever. Alex drinks, then puts his glass down. Juliet drinks but drain her glass. David sits still.
What's the problem?
I want to talk now.
After you drink to love and happiness forever.
Now.
After.
David, I promise we will. Keep him happy.
It's not for me. It's for love and happiness forever. David reaches out to take his glass. Suddenly, Alex fling out to point, knocking over David's glass and completely interest.
(CONTINUED)
Look over there. It's Cameron.
Who?
Cameron. You remember Cameron.
No, I don't.
What's he doing here?
That's not him.
Yes, it is. It's him. Cameron, Cameron, come on over.Yo! From some distance away, Cameron becomes aware of Alex an cautiously makes his way across until he stands a few fee the table.
What?
Nothing. We thought you were someone else. Alex falls forward, laughing, and the other two also laug Cameron walks away, humiliated again.
(CONTINUED)
Good luck. I love that guy, but why does he have to follo around?
Anyway, what I was wanting to say was this --
(UNSEEN)
The divine Juliet. Long time no see. Brian approaches and is standing behind their table.
Brian.
Would you care to dance?
Hold on there. Who do you think you are?
What?
Who do you think you are? You interrupted us.
I'm Brian McKinley, and who are you?

Well, Brian McKinley, if you want to talk to my girlfrien talk to me first. If you want to dance with her, then you in writing three weeks in advance or you're gonna end up fucking bin-bag. You didn't apply, so you don't dance. Shocked and frightened, Brian backs away, then turns arou complete his departure. Juliet restrains David with a tou they watch him go.
Do you think you could be a little more forceful next tim
I'm sorry.
It's alright. I think he got the message anyway.
That was stressful. I found that stressful.
Yeah, but you were good, you were really good. Fucking bi I liked that. You were good. You explored your maleness t full there.
You think so?
Well, you certainly had a good look around.
You were magnificent.

The gents' toilet. Brightly-lit and white-tiled. Alex wal goes into a cubicle and closes the door. We hear him whis and laughing as he passes urine. He keeps muttering bin-b himself. Then he flushes the toilet and opens the door. A does so a look of surprise appears on his face as he sees waiting for him.
Cameron! What a surprise. As Alex is speaking Cameron's fist flies forward, hitting the face and sending him flying backwards. Cameron enters cubicle and closes the door behind him.
Mail falls through the letter box. INT. KITCHEN. MORNING. Alex does not stir.
David emerges from his room, ready for his work. He looks the kitchen, then walks to the door and opens it.
We hear the main door closing as David leaves. Alex jolts energy with every sound. The telephone begins to ring. Ju looks at Alex expectantly, but he does not move. Eventual gets up and answers it.
Hello. Hello.
Who was it?
Don't know. No one said anything.
Rendered speechless with desire. I recall that feeling, f days when I had such a thing.
Are you all right?
No.
Then let's spend some money.
There follows a video depicting the results of Alex's and Juliet's spending spree. It opens with Alex seated at the table talking to the camera, absolutely deadpan.

Hello. It's been a struggle, but now the days of worry ar the light at the end of the tunnel has expanded into a go sunrise and at last, at long last, nothing will ever be t again. Alex leans out and the camera foloows him as he presses t button on a tape recorder. The music begins. Fast cuts follow, occasionally interrupted by out-of-focu of the floor or ceiling as the camera swivels round and i switched on and off. Alex wearing several different suits, outfits and silk py Juliet wearing several different outfits. Both of them posing with small objets d'art. The expensive watch on Alex's wrist. Juliet's jewellery. Expensive toys. Juliet takes a picture of Alex with a Polaroid camera. Alex holds the camcorder out at arm's length in order to himself and turns to the camera and adjusts his tie.
(CONTINUED)
This is Alex Law reporting from the scene of his own life you know, I'm so happy I could die. Darkness. TV. Turned off.

The music has stopped. David presses the eject button and lifts the video from t player. Alex and Juliet are seated on the sofa, surrounded by the acquisitions, and are evidently a little embarrassed. Jul holding the Polaroid of Alex.
I think we ought to scrub this, don't you? David reinserts the tape and presses record.
Will you calm down.
Yeah, you're making us all nervous. David picks up the Polaroid of Alex and throws it down, t picks up a vase.
How much did you pay?
I don't know.
How much did you pay?
I don't know.
How much?
I don't know.
Two hundred.
Two hundred pounds?
Two hundred pounds.
You paid two hundred pounds for this?
That's what it cost, David.

No, no, no. That's what you paid for it. Two hundred poun what you paid for it. We don't know what it cost us yet, two to have a good time, we don't know the cost of that y From out in the hall, the phone starts to ring. Nobody mo
David lies awake in his bed.
Hearing the noise, David sits up in bed, then gets out, r for his clothes.

David looks down the stairwell. Other neighbours, in nigh or hurriedly dressed, are standing at the open door of th below. David descends the the stairs and looks into the h the other flat where the occupant, an Elderly Woman, lies groaning on the floor. A hand on David's shoulder pushes him out of the way and uniformed policemen walk past, followed by an ambulance m carrying a stretcher.
Did they take anything? Did they take anything? No one acknowledges his question or answers it. The ambulance men emerge carrying the woman, her face bru cut. Everyone else begins to melt away.
David stands alone on the darkened stairwell.
David lies awake in his bed.

head_text.subj: INT. DOOR OF THE FLAT. DAY

text: Someone attempts to open the door but cannot because ther two new security chains on the inside. The door is forced the chains with no success and Alex calls from the other
What is this? What is going on? David! David approaches the door.
I'll let you in. David closes the door and looks through a new spyhole to grinning at him while he releases the chains and then ope door again. Alex walks in.
What is this?
Security.
From what? Jehovah's Witnesses?
There was a break-in.
Downstairs, I know. Pensioner's terror ordeal: page six. Alex hands David a rolled-up newspaper.
Doesn't it worry you?

No, it doesn't. I tried to let it worry me but it won't. worked on that paper for three years. There is a pensione terror ordeal on page six every day. Every day. Maybe whe pensioner it'll worry me. Alex notices some more tools and the stepladder leading u trapdoor.
(CONTINUED)
What's all this for, more security?
I fitted a lock up there. On the inside.
Oh, that'll come in useful.
Alex is serving on plates from a large bowl of pasta. David and Juliet sit at the tabel.
Is this the same stuff you made last week?
No, no, it's different.
I hope it tastes better than the other stuff.
It tastes different.
I don't want it to taste different. I don't know why I bo that enough for you? Hey!
What? Yes, that's fine.
You're sure? There's lots more.
No, I'm sure, that'll be enough.
What's wrong?
Nothing.
You're not eating.
Not eating what?
Not eating like you used to, that's what.
If you give me the plate, I'll eat. Alex hands him the plate and he starts to eat. Alex watch chew a mouthful.
Now swallow. David does so.
(CONTINUED)
You know, you should spend some of that money instead of about it. That's my advice.
He's right. You'd feel much better about it. David has stopped eating.
Once it's spent you won't have to worry about it.
Be like a weight off your shoulders.
You know we're right.
Don't you?
I want to secure it.
Secure it? What do you mean -- you're gong to take it to You're not going to take it to a bank? You're not going t it to a bank Or what, you want to bury it? Is that it?
I don't see the point in that.

Because that's no good. Remember, we did what we did, we money. It was a material calculation. But what's the use underground, or in some funny bank in some funny place? I can't spend it, if you can't have it, what use is it? Non nothing, all for nothing, if you do that. I didn't get in for nothing, so that I could have nothing --
Yeah, and you didn't saw his feet off. There is silence. David resumes eating.
(CONTINUED)
It tastes different.
Alex stands at the sink doing some washing up. He hears f from the loft above. He stops what he is doing and walks out ot the hall.
In the darkness we can just make out David's eyes as he s darkness.

(calling from below) David, David, what are you doing up there? The torch goes on. David lifts the bag of money from betw rafters. He puts it inside another thick yellow plastic b which he ties tightly with string. David opens the water tank. Alex's voice can be heard throughout.
(continued; calling from below) Will you come down now. It's not safe up there. Are you l to me. Security and insanity are not the same thing.
Shit.
Juliet sits drinking coffee, while Alex sands in the door looking up towards the trapdoor.
Leave him alone.
He can't stay up there.
He'll come down. Leave him alone.
Yeah, he's got to go to work, hasn't he? You think he'll down for that?
No, but he's looking after the money, so what's the probl
Looking after it -- he's probably fucking well eating it.

Juliet looks through the door from a small office out int main waiting area in the casualty departmet. It is busy a are rooms of people nursing injuries waiting to be seen. file past the door while she watches with no enthusiasm.
The trapdoor opens. David's head appears. He looks around listens carfeully.
Lumsden answers his telephone.
David speaks on the telephone.
It's my mother, sir, she's very ill and I think I need to her just now. I don't know. The doctors aren't sure. It c either way. Yes, sir, I'll certainly stay in touch.
David shaves carefully with a safety razor.
Bacon and eggs fry in a pan. David attends to them while from a large tumbler of orange juice.
A Sister hands Juliet a casualty case sheet. Juliet reads
Painful groin? What does that mean?
I don't know. He wouldn't show me. Juliet draws back the curtain of a cubicle. Alex is sitti trolly.
Boy, am I glad to see you.
What are you doing here?
We have to talk.
Your painful groin? She turns and walks away. Alex chases after her.
Later. But first -- him.
David?
Exactly. Now I've been thinking --
Oh, good.
He won't do anything for me, but for you --
Forget it.
He isn't safe up there. If you really cared about him, yo your influence to get him down, then he'd be safe.
And the money?
We could put it somewhere.
Where he can't get it?
Now you thought of that, not me.
Forget it -- he'll come down. Juliet walks away.
The hall is empty and the flat is silent. We see the trap
David sits in the darkness. A crack of light penetrates b the trapdoor.
Alex and Juliet sit at the table, eating in silence. The doorbell rings. Alex and Juliet look at one another.
Expecting anyone?
No.
Oh. Alex resumes eating.
Aren't you going to answer it?
Well, I'm not expecting anyone either. Juliet glares at him.
Alex approaches the door and is about to open it. At the moment he checks himself and looks through the spyhole.
Tim and Andy stand outside the door.

Alex, slightly puzzled, fixes the security chains before the door. As soon as he opens it, the door is kicked wide the security chains break off. Tim and Andy enter the fla In a whirlwind of force they drag and shove Alex and Juli the living room and bind them up with cord. There are no apart from slightly muffled cries. At the end of this Andy stands in front of Alex holding a crowbar. Swiftly and without warning, he cracks it across shins. Then Andy slowly puts one one end of the crowbar i Alex's mouth. For a moment he does nothing, then just as again, he takes the crowbar out.
It's in the loft.
The trapdoor is closed but the sound of it being unlocked just be heard (although not by anyone in the flat.
Tim pulls the ladder across to the trapdoor.
It is completely dark in the loft, but as the trapdoor op shaft of light strikes upwards and illuminates a small po around the opening.
Away from the trapdoor there appears to be a wall of unif darkness, but then we see a pair of eyes in the darkness. David. He stands perfectly still. There is a hammer in his right hand.
Tim's head appears through the trapdoor. Cautiously he li himself through and balances on the beams.
The hall is empty, but we can see the open trapdoor. Sudd there is a single thud, as might be caused by a body land heavily on and across some beams in the loft.
David stands motionless in the dark, exactly as before.

Andy has heard the single thud. He strains to hear anythi but does not. Slowly he backs away to the door of the liv room, keeping the crowbar trained on Alex as he does so. back and up towards the trapdoor.

Once again a small pool of light emanates from the open t Andy emerges into the front of this, crowbar in hand, pee into the darkness. Carefully he stands up and moves out o light and steps across the beams. His foot strikes someth he looks down. Tim's body lies spread-eagled beneath him. looks up. To one side of him is the brass light switch. A lifts his arm, reaches towards it and switches it on. Spa out for a moment and then the light comes on for a fracti second, long enough for Andy to see David's face is only  centimetres from his own.

Alex and Juliet are bound together as before. There is a thud from the ceiling, following by a few heavy steps. Th Andy's body falls headfirst through the trapdoor, straigh to the floor below, landing awkwardly and coming to rest head hanging back, looking towards Alex and Juliet. Andy one agonal breath and dies. Blood trickles from the side mouth. Tim's body lands on Andy. David drops himself from the hatch to the floor. David takes a large knife from a wooden block. Back in the hall he kneels, holding the knife, beside Tim Noticing something at the top of tim's neck, he uses the lift away Tim's T-shirt. A tattoo covers Tim's neck. Davi at it, then stands up. He walks through to the living room, where Alex and Julie bound, watch him approach. He looks at them for a moment, extends the knife and cuts the cord in one place.
In a scene similar to the dismemberment of Hugo, we see D shoulders as he saws back and forth at something unseen. and reaches out for the hammer, picks it up and raises it his head.
The van is silhouetted against a rising sun.

head_text.subj: INT. BACK OF THE VAN. DAWN

text: The tools and the yellow sack slide about in the back of
David is driving. Alex and Juliet are huddled silently aw him. David seems quite at ease. A thick bunch of keys dangles from the ignition. Juliet o them.
David sits still in the darkness.

Alex sits at his desk fidgeting, about to write something unable to start. On the screen of his word processor is a mock-up with the headline CATS EAT PENSIONER'. As the tel on his desk rings, he is startled, then reaches out, slow it fractionally and replaces it.
Hunched over a VDU, the Salesman is offering Juliet a ran flights.
October 15th, direct flight, London Heathrow to Rio de Ja British Airways, you are looking at seven hundred and six pounds. Seven six five.
That sounds fine.
Air Portugal, on the other hand, via Lisbon, same day, fi hundred and sixty-five. Five six five. It's up to you. Ca important?
What?
Air France. Glasgow. Direct, but then you're looking at t end of nine hundred and twelve pounds. That's nine one tw up to you.
Yes, the first one's fine. Heathrow direct.
It's up to you. Air Patagonia. New outfit: via Caracas an . No catering. Four hundred and eleven pounds. Four one o value, but refueling at Bogot is variable.
The first one was fine.
Well, it's up to you. Seven six five. How will you be pay
The hall is empty but we can hear David's footsteps on th above.

Alex sits watching The Wicker Man on televison. He can he footsteps above. He turns the sound up on the television he cannot hear them, but he keeps looking up at the ceili though he expects to hear them or see somwthing. Eventually he turns the sound back down and, after a mome silence, the footsteps start again, back and forth, then Alex looks up. Without warning there is the sound of an electric drill. The blade of the drill appears through the ceiling and is withdrawn. Alex is shocked. Other drill holes appear.
Holes are drilled in the ceilings.
Rods of light penetrate up from the holes, interrupting b obliterating the darknes. David sits back, pleased with h
Juliet sits at her desk. Alex stands in the doorway. He i to speak. Juliet raises a finger to her lips. They both l the ceiling.

head_text.subj: EXT. GARDEN AT FRONT OF THE FLAT. NIGHT

text: Establishing shot of Alex and Juliet in garden.
The trapdoor is open.
David is searching through Alex's desk, looking through l and folders, then shoving them back into drawers.

head_text.subj: EXT. GARDEN AT THE FRONT OF THE FLAT. NIGHT

text: No, definitely not. And that's that. I refuse to discuss further.
It's the only way.
I refuse.
You're frightened.

No, I'm not frightened. A little terrified maybe. Did you what happened to the last two who tried that? They went u and they came down dead -- the difference, I mean, alive dead alive, that sort of thing. It wasn't difficult to sp killed them both: he cut them up.
David is now searching through Juliet's desk. He picks up brown envelope and looks into it. Beneath it is the airli ticket envelope. The doorbell rings.
McCall and Mitchell stand outside the door.
David opens the door. McCall smiles.
Good evening. I'm Detective Inspector McCall and this is Mitchell. I wonder if we could ask you some questions.
What about?
It's about the burglary.
Burglary?
Downstairs.
Of course.
Can we come in?
David sits on the sofa while the two policemen sit on arm several feet apart.

So I just heard her cries for help and all that, and when downstairs there were already those other people there, s stood around really, waiting -- you know how people do -- then when your colleagues arrived I came back upstairs. A that's about all, I think. I didn't actually see anything I don't think.
did you hear anything before he cries?
No, not that I recall, I was asleep.
Have you seen anything or anyone suspicious around here i last few days?
No, nothing, sorry.
Well, if you do, you'll let us know?
Of course.
And the other three people on the flat, did they hear any
There are only two other people in the flat.  McCall consults a notebook.
Two?
Who said there were four?
We understood there were four people living here. Not alw course, but now, four.
No, three. Who said there were four?
How strange. And how unsatisfactory to have misleading  information. Only three people here. You're sure?
Yes, absolutely.
Take a note of that, Mitchell. Only three, rather than fo Write it down. You can use numbers or words, I have no  preference. Which are you using?
Both, sir.
Excellent. DC Mitchell is a rising star, Mr. Stevens. Und tutelage he will undoubtedly make the grade.
I see.
I doubt it. And these two other people, did they hear any
No, they were asleep. They didn't even wake up.
Yes. Why do you think you woke and they didn't?
I don't know. Maybe I'm a light sleeper. Uncomfortably, David realizes that Mitchell has noted dow this last, trivial remark in a painful longhand and has  underlined a short segment of it.
In the hallway of the flat Mitchell stands at the open ma waiting to leave. McCall is kneeling at the door to Hugo' tracing his finger down the broken lintel and lock. David on.
Loks like you had a break-in up here as well.
Someone lost the key. McCall gently pushes the door open and the light from the illuminates Hugo's room.
Is this where no one stays?
Yeah, that's right, that's it. David notices that Mitchell is writing this down.

head_text.subj: INT. GARDEN AT FRONT OF THE FLAT. NIGHT

text: You'll wait in the hall?
I'll wait there.
And if it sounds like I'm being killed, you'll phone the you'll tell them everything?
Everything.
Everything. Except maybe that it was his idea and not min first place. OK? That's important to me. I need to die  misunderstood.
Alex.
What?
As smart as you are, you'll need a little help. She hands Alex a Yale key. Alex stares at it.
In the darkness, the sound of the lock being turned is he
Alex tsands at the top of the ladder, holding the key in trapdoor lock.

All right, David, what I'm going to do is, I'm going to o lock and I'm going to come up, and what's important is th remain calm. There is one light on. Juliet stands at the bottom of the Having opened the trapdoor, Alex stops and listens, but t no sound above his own breathing. Juliet throws up a torc he catches. He switches it on. It shines, then goes out, knocks it against the ladder, making it work again. Slowl pushes the trapdoor open.

The trapdoor opens. Below it, Alex crouches on the ladder expecting attack at any moment. He looks back down to Jul returns his gaze, then he slowly raises himself into the He turns around quickly, darting the torchlight around in corners and squinting in the darkness, but he sees nothin The torch goes out. Cursing, he knocks it against a beam shines again. Slowly he moves further from the trapdoor into the centre loft, still turning around and worried about what might b him.
Juliet stands waiting, braced for sounds of conflict.
Alex is still looking but has relaxed a little, feeling l danger. In one corner he notices David's pile of left-pos and the mat on which he has been sleeping. He moves towar
Juliet stands, still waiting.
Alex stands in David's corner. With another sweep of the can still see nothing. He calls to Juliet.
He isn't up here.

A close-up of Juliet's face, just as David's hand slams a her mouth, gripping her tightly while his other hand clam the back of her head. David's mouth is right up against h as he spits a warning into it.
Tell him to look for the money. Slowly, David relaxes his grip on Juliet.
Look for the money.
Alex, cheerful now, is looking in the rafters.
Don't worry, that's what I'm doing.
David holds Juliet across her face again. She is terrifie does not struggle.
Expecting anyone?
What?
Were you expecting anyone? Tonight?
No.
Visitors? Some friends maybe? Someone you talked to?
No one. I promise.
Who have you talked to?
No one.
If I think you're lying --
Alex stands gazing around the loft.
(from the loft) Well, it's not up here.
David pulls Juliet to one side.

Alex is about to descend when he notices the water tank. over and lifts the lid. His face breaks into a smile as h realizes what it holds. He dips an arm into the tank, rai yellow bag, then quickly lowers it again. Alex steps back the water tank.
Alex appears at the top of the ladder. Without looking, h down as quickly as he can, calling out as he does so.
Juliet, I have -- Alex reaches the base of the ladder. He turns around to f himself facing the blade of the battery-operated drill, h David. Juliet stands off to one side.
(CONTINUED)
-- a problem. David holds the drill even closer until it is almost touc centre of Alex's forehead and presses the trigger' to tur blade slowly as he speaks. Alex does not move at all.
You looking for me?
Looking for you? Yes.
What for? What did you want? The money? Was that it?
We just wanted to speak to you. Alex's hands and sleeves are wet. A few drops of water fa his fingertips. Unnoticed by the other two, he slowly wip hands on the back of his jeans.
Who else have you wanted to speak to? Maybe you thought t already got me. The blade os the drill scrapes Alex's skin.
Who?
Your friends.
I don't know what you're talking about.
He doesn't know David. David holds the drill back slightly while he thinks. It c either way.
Well, maybe you don't -- David lowers the drill and smiles.
(CONTINUED)
I'm talking about the police.
Alex has just woken up. He rubs his forehead. There is a it, where the drill has scratched. He rubs at it and exam drop of blood on the end of his finger.

head_text.subj: INT. DAVID'S POINT OF VIEW. ALEX'S ROOM. DAY

text: Looking down from a hole in the ceiling, we see into Alex where he is getting dressed.
Alex leaves his room and enters the hall.
Looking down from a hole in the ceiling, we see into Alex where he is getting dressed.
Looking down on Alex as he leaves the flat and closes the
David scurries back across the beams to look down through hole. He looks for several seconds. NOTE In the following sequence, Juliet's face is not seen her comment on it.
Juliet lies on her bed. She throws the covers back.
David is still looking down through the hole.

David still watching.
